timeline.message:
Allow JSSEngine.wrap/unwrap of large buffers

Because JSSEngine wraps the native NSS, there are two places data can be
buffered:

 - Within JSSEngine's internal buffers,
 - Within NSS's internal buffers.

When the handshake has completed, we need to ensure we always drain as
much data as possible from these buffers into wrap/unwrap. This requires
us to invoke multiple calls to PR.Read and PR.Write, until they
eventually return EWOULDBLOCK or 0 data written.

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

timeline.author: cipherboy

timeline.message:
Handle JSSEngine.putData(...) with large arrays

When data and the destination buffer are roughly the same, and both
suitably large, it makes more sense to use ByteBuffer.put(...) with
the source array (providing offset and lengths) rather than manually
putting each byte into the buffer.

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

timeline.bodyText: According to the doc, GetByteArrayElements() will only return NULL if it fails, so I think the code should terminate immediately if buffer is NULL.

timeline.bodyText: @edewata Can you think of anything more elegant for this? Or is adding a boolean flag and tracking it fine? Maybe I should split it into a updateHandshakePre() and a updateHandshakeState()? -- Pre only getting called once and State getting called only when actually handshaking? Hmm...
timeline.author: cipherboy

replies.bodyText:
I don't really have an opinion on this. If it works then let's keep it :)
We can always refactor later if we find a better way.
I've ACKed this PR, feel free to merge, but I'd prefer @jmagne to take a look at this as well, either before or after merging.
replies.author: edewata

timeline.bodyText: I"m assuming that this_src_write and ths_dst_write will eventually become exactly zero?
timeline.author: jmagne

replies.bodyText:
Yeah, I need to update the docs pr (#428) with this. But the theory is this: Let's take wrap as an example. We need to take data from src and put it into dst if the handshake has finished. Otherwise if we're still handshaking we need to take whatever handshake data is made and puts it into dst.
So let's take the handshaking scenario:

We'll be ignoring src because PR.Write(...) will fail until the handshake is complete.
So UpdateHandshakeState() will write data into the write buffer.
We'll drain data from the read buffer and write it into dst.

During this:

this_src_write will be 0 because PR.Write(...) returns 0 / PR_WOULD_BLOCK until handshake completes.
While we're still handshaking in this step, UpdateHandshakeState() will write into the read buffer, which then goes into dst, incrementing this_dst_write.
When we run out of handshake data to write, UpdateHandshakeState() will quit writing data (and return PR_WOULD_BLOCK) and this_dst_write will go to data as the write buffer will be empty.


A similar thing applies when src is non-empty and we're not handshaking:

We'll be writing from src into the SSL PRFileDesc *. PR.Write(...) returns number of bytes written which ends up into this_src_write. As long as we're still writing data (and not getting an error / PR_WOULD_BLOCK), this'll be non-zero. It'll also continue being non-zero while there's space in the write buffer. However, this write buffer gets cleared out by the last step...
UpdateHandshakeState() will return, a no-op because we're not handshaking.
When there's src data and PR.Write() succeeds, there'll be data in the write buffer so we'll be able to put it in dst and this_dst_write will be non-zero. Otherwise, if src fails, this_src_write becomes 0 and there'll be nothing in the write buffer so this_dst_write will go to 0 as well.


In all helper methods, we guarantee that on error, 0 is returned instead of a less than zero value.

In both cases, when we run out of handshake and/or src data, we'll quit writing to the write buffer and this_dst_write will eventually go to 0 as well.
replies.author: cipherboy

timeline.message:
Add test case for large wrap/unwrap

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

Allow dummy PR.Write with NULL buffer

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

Allow JSSEngine.wrap/unwrap of large buffers

Because JSSEngine wraps the native NSS, there are two places data can be
buffered:

 - Within JSSEngine's internal buffers,
 - Within NSS's internal buffers.

When the handshake has completed, we need to ensure we always drain as
much data as possible from these buffers into wrap/unwrap. This requires
us to invoke multiple calls to PR.Read and PR.Write, until they
eventually return EWOULDBLOCK or 0 data written.

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

Gate socket logging behind debug flag

This debug logging is broken for large messages because it timesout
trying to write data. Disable it by default unless explicitly recompiled
with support in the test suite.

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

Handle JSSEngine.putData(...) with large arrays

When data and the destination buffer are roughly the same size, and both
suitably large, it makes more sense to use ByteBuffer.put(...) with
the source array (providing offset and lengths) rather than manually
putting each byte into the buffer.

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

Handle PR.Writes of smaller sizes in JSSEngine

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

Return FINISHED status from JSSEngine.{un,}wrap

When handling large messages, updateHandshakeState() gets called
multiple times during handshaking. If the handshake becomes FINISHED
and data gets written to a buffer, we'll call updateHandshakeState()
again, resulting in it immediately moving to NOT_HANDSHAKING. Because
clients expect a FINISHED message before NOT_HANDSHAKING, only step
further after FINISHED has been returned from either wrap or unwrap.

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

Return FINISHED status from JSSEngine.{un,}wrap

When handling large messages, updateHandshakeState() gets called
multiple times during handshaking. If the handshake becomes FINISHED
and data gets written to a buffer, we'll call updateHandshakeState()
again, resulting in it immediately moving to NOT_HANDSHAKING. Because
clients expect a FINISHED message before NOT_HANDSHAKING, only step
further after FINISHED has been returned from either wrap or unwrap.

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>
